comments.commentBody: They will respond when there are just too many of us in the streets holding torches and pitchforks.

The more I think of it the more the Russian ladies of the night relieving themselves on a bankrupt degenerate who stole the presidency with a Putin (net worth $200 billion the richest man in the world) assist seems increasingly plausible.
I thought they relieved themselves on a bed the Obamas had slept in. It was an act of disrespect if so.

If you believe:
- Trump paid ladies of the night to relieve themselves in the bed where the Obama's slept while he was watching them doing it as an act of disrespect;
- or if the degenerate in our White House enjoyed having it done on him,
- or if we are both correct and Trump paid ladies of the night relieve themselves on him while in the bed where the Obama's had slept,
it does not matter.

In any of these scenarios Trump would be out of the White House if a video of ANY of these possibilities surfaces. This means given Trump's repeated calls to go easy on Putin and going as far as making excuses for Putin when people accused that Putin is a killer by saying WE ALL DO KILLINGS!!! I personally would like to go to the bottom of it if a Trump appointee is caught lying about having talked to Russian agents as Sessions was caught to have done.

"Though we don’t have a state-run media, we do live in a society in which the president’s face and messages are sufficiently omnipresent to give Mao or Lenin a run for their money. When is the last time you went a day without seeing the “great leader”?"

I think Mr. Wu misses a huge point. While Trump may be in his element, basking in the glow of nonstop coverage and having virtually no competition for "clicks," isn't it impossible for him to hide anything?

Riding into office on a major scandal involving a foreign adversary state, Mr. Trump can no longer escape the glare, or get away with things when there were more GOP faces to deal with. "There ain't no place to hide," Mr. President, as a growing interest in all things Russian threatens to expose more malfeasance.

Trump may be 'winning" in mindshare, but serious news publications are enjoying record new subscriptions. Think print media is dead? Hard copies may be down but digital access is booming, as many a political junkie gets high on the drumbeat of reporter allegations.

I believe the attention Trump craves will undo him in the end. You can't live in a fishbowl without somebody noticing when the seaweed risks choking off your oxygen supply. In other words, attention is a double-edged sword: great for ratings until it turns.

Isn't it possible that the "witch hunt" Trump decries might end up revealing the messy murky truth behind the most untruthful President in US history?

An investigation without an independent bipartisan commission is an invitation to disaster. With the GOP controlling both houses of Congress the outcome is preordained.  Insufficient evidence! We will then be doomed to four years of the free press working on proving that there was a cover up. If Trump wants to  put this behind him, he must demand that it be taken out of the hands of a very partisan Congress. Then and only then will the American Public know the truth.

Sessions did not lie - IMO, based on seeing the video clip of the question posed to Sessions.  The question was in the context of being a Trump campaign surrogate.  Sessions answer was in that context - not the context of being an active US Senator who met with 25+ ambassadors that week.   So, it seems to me that the Times is sucked into the ire the Democrats have for the Russian e-mail invasion - and a come from nowhere victory of Donald Trump!!!!!

My grandmother remarried a wonderful man; entrepreneur/automotive parts business founder/orchid grower/every Sunday baptist. She moved from Tudor City to Greenville, S.C. and always the chamillion, became the sweet tea fixin', Cadillac driving,  Miss Daisy...complete with 'black help'. I was the visiting 'Yankee' grandson. I met many an "aw shucks" Jeff Sessions in Greenville. It was the '70s and they longed for the '50s, '40s, '30s, '20s.  If you pumped gas, cleaned a house, washed a car and minded your business you were a 'good n.....'. Anything more wasn't tolerated. For old men of that era, racism and xenophobia are hard wired. At 70, only an exceptional man in a movie, novel or faced with death will change. Jeff Sessions drank the Trump Tea, paid for his trip to Cleveland as a campaign operative, met a Russian Ambassador as a campaign operative, and failed to disclose that under oath. While the perjury bar is high, the ethics bar is lower and, for the Trumpists, the truth bar was cast away long ago.

"It’s quite possible, along with the greater issue of “seeding” by Obama era officials of unsubstantiated innuendo implying traitorous actions by Trump’s campaign team, that Trump now will see no alternative but to respond in kind, going after “enemies” with unsubstantiated innuendo."

Since when do we have to leave Trump "no alternative" before he will go'...after "enemies" with unsubstantiated innuendo?" Anybody see Obama's birth certificate lately?

Fire Sessions - an AG that lies - with a smirk on his face is a liar. The Trump lemmings may swallow the lies but not the rest of us. The "government " is spinning out of control - thanks to Trump's belief that he is infallible. I think McConnell, Pence, and Ryan need to be questioned too. Trust is earned not purchased with trip to FL. Sessions should never have been confirmed.

I think its the Republicans who have majorities in both House and Senate that has the authority to begin a special prosecution. But you know what? They really really want 1) to get re-elected, 2) Get a really big tax cut for the base, 3) Deregulate, again for the base, 4) Get re-elected and serve well into their 80's.
So, no I don't see a special prosecutor being appointed anytime in the next four years.
The base won't get the payola from the tax cuts.  Those are for Wall Street as the swamp in lower Manhattan sluices in to Foggy Bottom.

The key question is: why lie? If Sessions met with Kislyak for reasons unconnected to the Trump campaign, which is highly doubtful, then why not tell the truth? Why, with the knowledge that 17 US Intelligence Agencies unanimously concluded that Russia intentionally and successfully interfered in our national election, would Sessions not have revealed his meetings with Kislyak? He had plenty of opportunity to do so, including 30 days after the hearing in which to amend his testimony.

The second key question is: why are all these Trump campaign associates meeting with Russians? In the context of Trump's inexplicable and unrelenting alignment with Putin, why would Sessions, Manafort, Flynn, Page, Jared Kushner, Stone, and likely others not yet named -- why would all these people intimately involved in Trump's campaign and administration have any need to meet with Russians during the campaign and the transition period?

When the lying makes no sense, and the need for all these conversations with Russians leave you scratching your head, you can be sure the underlying reason is a serious one. Serious, and seriously wrong.

During the campaign, Sessions mildly rebuked Trump about asking for Russian espionage by saying that he believed politics ended at water's edge. That was another lie from Sessions. He was willing to immerse himself covertly with Russia - and shrug off all the Russian ties with Trump and his inner circle.
Wherever Sessions conceives of the water's edge, it is far from the United States to him. He does not deserve to head our Justice Department.

So now we have a twist on the old Las Vegas line: "What happens in Cleveland, stays in Cleveland"?

The level of protest must continue to be ratcheted up until even the ideologically blind GOP Congress does its duty and open investigations of this assault on our Republic by Russia, and what role Trump and his minions had in it.

The time to choose whose side your on - your party's or the People is now Congress, and history will judge your choice.

If this were the first 100 days of the Obama administration, the right wing wage machine would have been hyperventilating and there would have been gunfire in the streets. Oh the incompetence, stinking corruption, treachery and scandal the Republicans have brought to the centers of government after championing themselves as the paragons of virtue and morality. Take a good look America.

"Bystanders" we might be, but "apologists" we most certainly are not.

"Republicans" and "solution" in the same sentence? From this lot? The Party-first-and-the-devil-take-the-hindmost set? It is not "contempt" that we have, it is just clear-eyed and disappointed acceptance of the truth. In another era the Dems and the Repubs differed on philosophy but their love of the country was never in question. Now we have McConnell and Ryan for whom the end justifies anything and everything, and the means are not even a consideration. For shame.

comments.userLocation: Fair Verona where we lay our scene
comments.commentBody:
Hillary Clinton created one corporation in her life, one dealing with Whitewater during that particular spree of defrauding people. It failed.
Your President Trump has created hundreds of corporations in his business career and over 99% of them are still conducting business as we read comments here.

Make sure there aren't any Russians in your fridge tonight before going to bed!

I certainly would not want to provoke unjustified suspicion of the innocent, but sometimes I am tempted to think that the greatest number of Republicans in the Senate and House of Representatives---where already they form the majority---are living by double standards.  I am shocked, shocked to find myself so thinking!

Perhaps the most alarming thing is that Sessions had to be advised by staff that he should recuse himself. The country's top lawyer apparently couldn't work that out for himself. That alone should disqualify him from the job.

Having an impish smile does not mitigate having brutal opinions. And it's one thing for him not to recognise that he lacks any sort of moral compass but beyond comprehension that so many are prepared to turn a blind eye to the fact in the name of party political advantage

Trump's was a campaign built on lies, half-truths and nasty innuendos. It's now an ineradicable habit for this administration, with a leadership that has gleefully plunged into that fetid pool many times.

I have absolutely no reason to expect that these ingrained habits - and the lack of ethics that go with them - will change any time soon.

Bill Clinton lied under oath and Congress spent $64 million in taxpayer money investigating him only to discover he was covering up an affair of the heart. Jeff Sessions lies under oath about contact with a foreign government already implicated in a crime--hacking Hillary Clinton's and the Dems' emails--and he not only gets a "get out of jail" free card from Trump, but his fellow Congressmen allow him a "do-over" that he can submit in writing. Only five weeks in, there is a rotten odor in the Trump administration and it comes from the top.

Un pesce puzza dalla testa.
It's Italian. A fish stinks from the head.

.
.
""What to Do with Jeff Sessions"?

The standard for perjury, contempt of Congress, or removal from office would be thorny. The President will be of no help because he's busy coming up with excuses for not releasing tax returns.

Hmm. Well, Richard Nixon wasn't impeached, but he was disbarred by one of the states where he was licensed to practice law. Bill Clinton was humorously impeached and found not guilty. He was suspended by the Akandas Bar, ordered to pay a fine, and permitted to apply for full reinstatement to the Bar. He didn't bother.

As a Senator, Jeff Sessions committed acts sufficient to be grounds for suspension or disbarment fron Alabama courts or whatever federal courts have admitted him to practice. That includes the Supreme Court of the United States.

Federal judges need not be attorneys. What about Justice Dep't lawyers? Let's find out. Someone please put in a complaint saying Jeff Sessions should be disbarred for [name the reasons].

Sessions will be outside the legal profession. Can he still be Attorney General?

[While we're at it, White House Senior Adviser for Lies, Kellyanne Conway, has broken a few ethics rules. Disbar her from the New Jersey State Bar. Others will follow.]

"The hanky panky with the Russia (sic) pretty much all happened before Trump took office."

Many who follow the news would take issue with this comment due to the fact that NSA director Mike Flynn stepped down from his post for lying to VP Pence about the extent of his 5 phone calls to Russian diplomat Kislyak (coincidentally the same diplomat that Session lied about having no contacts with while under oath before Congress). We now know due to high level leaks to the media, that the NSA had monitored these phone calls that not so coincidentally occurred on the same day that then President Obama has expelled Russians for spying. The intelligence leaks gave privy to the public that General Flynn was not being forthright (similarly to Jess Sessions) about the extent of his ill timed phone calls to known Russian spy, Kislyak. Flynn had lied to the American public as well as ostensibly to VP Pence making it seem as if the phone calls were not attempts to assuage Russian anger & to curry favor while at the same time undermining President Obama's foreign policy which many would suggest was treasonous secretive behavior. The public now knows, thanks to White House or Intelligence leaks, that Trump's son-in-law with General Flynn had private talks with the same Russian diplomat that Flynn & Sessions lied about to the American public. To top it off, just days after Jared Kushner met with known Russian spy Kislyak, he negotiated deals with the Chinese for real estate development.

Strange times. It wasn't very long ago that anyone suspected of being a 'fellow traveler' was spied on, followed, hounded, outed and shamed. Most Americans knew a little something, even if not in detail, about Stalin and the death camps and purges that ripped the heart out of the USSR. The breakup of the Soviet Republic into the original nation states and the day the Berlin wall came down were celebrated as victories of the west over communism, Russia and the cold war. Tiny little communist Cuba! is still considered a bigger threat than anything else we can see close up, though we don't mind doing business there if there's money to be made (it's always about the money isn't it?). How in the world did the Republican party and its representatives move so, so quickly from evil empire/bad-Russian-bear to protecting and defending senior statesmen who lie about their actions consorting with "the enemy"?
Sessions has done the right thing by recusing himself from Russian matter. Though people feel whether it is a precursor of things for Trump like those were for Nixon during watergate
Any other employee would be fired.  If one of Sessions employees did something similar with him, he'd be gone instantly.  Rules don't apply to friends and appointees of Dear Leader.

Shumer, as you now know, is found in the frontispiece of Drudge bearing a smile and a beverage with Putin.  A cold one since the Cold War invokes warmth now.  But Sessions sessions with the Russian Ambassador make him unfit to be top cop.  And I voted for Obama twice, Trump once.  Why the hypnotist of Reality TV picked that Nathan Bedford Forest is a great mystery.  Trump is supposed to be the monkey wrench thrown at the machine.  The wrench bounced off,  hit me in the neck and I awoke afraid of the lout I hired.  And since all politics is locally self serving,  and Sessions is the king of disliking pot people, my buffet of cannabis stocks has lost about 30% so far from having Harry Anslinger reanimated to attack my future dreams of a cannabis legal windfall.  You all tried to feed me a Clinton, Sessions wants to steal my rolling papers, I'm down  over the counter unlike Buffet's buffet, and all the children are taking their Ritalin legally.  Those pills are sugared, believe it or not, to make them sweet for the little sweeties.  The top cop's opinion of drugs like that might remain a mystery if he is fired.  But V Jarrett and Clinton the Husband conversed on Comey with no repercussions except recusal ruining her day.  It was the Hillary disaster that took her down.  It took down The Times too, I don't subscribe since election day.  I came back to tell you I'm gone.  Up in smoke, down in wealth.
Hey, you know what?  People are allowed to speak to Russians!  We don't have a law against it.  What do we have a law against?  Lying to Congress.
@CF you are correct, I didn't mention he lied.  I forgot whilst smoking my assets.  But thank you for the legal advice.  OK, I just lied.
